title: 109_hr4709
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Telephone Records and Privacy Protection Act of 2006". It includes findings related to telephone records and privacy protection. Congress finds that telephone records contain personal data that can be exploited by criminals, including information on doctors, relationships, and business associates. These records are meant for authorized use only but have been obtained fraudulently through methods like employees selling data and pretexting. Unauthorized disclosure of telephone records poses a threat to individual privacy and can lead to acts of domestic violence, stalking, and compromise the safety of law enforcement officers, their families, victims of crime, witnesses, and confidential informants. It also undermines the integrity of law enforcement investigations. SEC. 3. FRAUD AND RELATED ACTIVITY IN CONNECTION WITH OBTAINING CONFIDENTIAL PHONE RECORDS INFORMATION OF A COVERED ENTITY. This section introduces a new offense related to obtaining confidential phone records information of a covered entity. Whoever knowingly and intentionally obtains confidential phone records information of a covered entity in interstate or foreign commerce through false statements, fraudulent representations, providing false documents, or unauthorized access to customer accounts, shall face fines, imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. Additionally, the sale or transfer of confidential phone records information is prohibited. Prohibition on the sale or transfer of confidential phone records information in interstate or foreign commerce without customer authorization or if obtained fraudulently. Violators may face fines, imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. Exceptions specified in section 222(d) of the Communications Act of 1934 apply for the use of such information by covered entities. (c) Prohibition on purchasing or receiving confidential phone records information in interstate or foreign commerce without customer authorization or if obtained fraudulently. Violators may face fines, imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. Exceptions specified in section 222(d) of the Communications Act of 1934 apply for the use of such information by covered entities. Enhanced penalties for aggravated cases. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving violations of subsections (a), (b), or (c) in conjunction with other illegal activities exceeding $100,000 or impacting more than 50 customers within a year. Offenders may face double fines and up to 5 years in prison. Additionally, enhanced penalties are imposed for using such information in furtherance of specified criminal offenses. In cases involving violations of certain subsections, offenders may face fines and up to 5 years in prison. Additionally, there is extraterritorial jurisdiction over offenses under this section. The law allows investigative activities by law enforcement and intelligence agencies at the federal, state, or local levels. It defines confidential phone records information as data related to services used by customers of a covered entity. The term 'covered entity' refers to telecommunications carriers and providers of IP-enabled voice service. A 'customer' is defined as an individual or entity receiving a product or service from a covered entity. The term 'IP-enabled voice service' refers to real-time voice communications transmitted through customer premises equipment using TCP/IP protocol with interconnection capability to the public switched telephone network. SEC. 4. SENTENCING GUIDELINES.

The United States Sentencing Commission will review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of fraud related to obtaining confidential phone records of a covered entity within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The Commission is authorized to make amendments following specified procedures.
